title: Milijana Nikolic
text:
Milijana Nikolic (or Nikolić; ; born 1975) is an <a href="opera">opera</a>tic <a href="mezzo-soprano">mezzo-soprano</a>.
Education.
Nikolic was born in <a href="Sremska%20Mitrovica">Sremska Mitrovica</a> where she began singing in the choir Sirmium Cantorum. She graduated in 2001 from the <a href="University%20of%20Arts%20in%20Belgrade">University of Arts in Belgrade</a>, tutored by Prof. <a href="Radmila%20Smiljani%C4%87">Radmila Smiljanić</a>.
Career.
Her stage debut was at the <a href="National%20Theatre%20in%20Belgrade">National Theatre in Belgrade</a> as Third Lady in Mozart's "<a href="The%20Magic%20Flute">The Magic Flute</a>"; she then sang Tisbe in Rossini’s "<a href="La%20Cenerentola">La Cenerentola</a>". In 2001, Nikolic won a two-year scholarship for the <a href="La%20Scala">Teatro alla Scala</a> Academy for the Specialisation of Opera Singers which allowed her to complete her studies under <a href="Leyla%20Gencer">Leyla Gencer</a>, <a href="Luciana%20Serra">Luciana Serra</a>, Giovanna Canetti, <a href="Luigi%20Alva">Luigi Alva</a> and <a href="Teresa%20Berganza">Teresa Berganza</a>, and further develop her operatic ability under the batons of <a href="Conducting">conductors</a> including <a href="Gary%20Bertini">Gary Bertini</a> and <a href="Riccardo%20Muti">Riccardo Muti</a>. At the academy, she <a href="Understudy">covered</a> <a href="Olga%20Borodina">Olga Borodina</a> as Delilah in Saint-Saëns' "<a href="Samson%20and%20Delilah%20%28opera%29">Samson and Delilah</a>", sang the Third Greek Lady in Gluck's "<a href="Iphig%C3%A9nie%20en%20Aulide">Iphigénie en Aulide</a>" under Riccardo Muti at the <a href="Teatro%20degli%20Arcimboldi">Teatro degli Arcimboldi</a>, Milan, Emma in Donizetti's "<a href="Ugo%2C%20conte%20di%20Parigi">Ugo, conte di Parigi</a>", a role she had sung before at the <a href="Teatro%20Donizetti">Teatro Donizetti</a> in <a href="Bergamo">Bergamo</a> and later sang again at the <a href="Teatro%20Massimo%20Bellini">Teatro Massimo Bellini</a> in Catania. At La Scala, she sang the principal role of Cuniza in Verdi's "<a href="Oberto%20%28opera%29">Oberto</a>", a production where her later husband <a href="Rosario%20La%20Spina">Rosario La Spina</a> sang Riccardo; this production then travelled to the <a href="Teatro%20Carlo%20Felice">Teatro Carlo Felice</a> in Genoa.
In 2006, Nikolic sang the role of Eboli in Verdi's "<a href="Don%20Carlos">Don Carlos</a>" in Seoul, Korea, and later reprised this role in 2008 for Opera Hong Kong. Other roles include Maddalena in Verdi’s "<a href="Rigoletto">Rigoletto</a>", Marchesa di Berkenfeld in Donizetti’s "<a href="La%20fille%20du%20r%C3%A9giment">La Figlia di Reggimento</a>" in 2004 at the Teatro Marrucino, <a href="Chieti">Chieti</a>, which has been released on CD for <a href="Naxos%20Records">Naxos Records</a>. In 2006, Nikolic sang La Baronne in Massenet's "<a href="Ch%C3%A9rubin">Chérubin</a>" and Fenena in Verdi's "<a href="Nabucco">Nabucco</a>" for the Teatro Lirico in <a href="Cagliari">Cagliari</a>, Sardinia.
Her collaboration with <a href="Opera%20Australia">Opera Australia</a> began in 2006, singing Ježibaba in Dvořák's "<a href="Rusalka%20%28opera%29">Rusalka</a>" and continued with performances as the Princess in Puccini's "<a href="Suor%20Angelica">Suor Angelica</a>", Azucena in Verdi's "<a href="Il%20trovatore">Il trovatore</a>" and Venus in Richard Wagner's "<a href="Tannh%C3%A4user%20%28opera%29">Tannhäuser</a>". Other roles for Opera Australia were in 2008 Ulrica in Verdi's "<a href="Un%20ballo%20in%20maschera">Un ballo in maschera</a>" and Adelaide in Richard Strauss' "<a href="Arabella">Arabella</a>". In March 2010, Nikolic created the role of Mrs Dalton in the world premiere of Brett Dean's opera "<a href="Bliss%20%28opera%29">Bliss</a>" and she will travel in 2011 with that production to the <a href="Edinburgh%20Festival">Edinburgh Festival</a>. Nikolic sang Amneris in Verdi's "<a href="Aida">Aida</a>" for Opera Australia in 2009 and in 2010 for Southern Opera, <a href="Christchurch">Christchurch</a>, New Zealand, and for <a href="Opera%20Queensland">Opera Queensland</a>. In July 2010, she sang the title role in Bizet's "<a href="Carmen">Carmen</a>" at the <a href="Savonlinna%20Opera%20Festival">Savonlinna Opera Festival</a> in Finland. She also sang the title role in Vivaldi's opera "<a href="Juditha%20triumphans">Juditha triumphans</a>" at the 2010 <a href="Macerata%20Opera">Sferisterio Opera Festival</a>.
In 2013, she alternated in the title role of "Carmen" with <a href="Rinat%20Shaham">Rinat Shaham</a> in Opera Australia's "Handa Opera on Sydney Harbour" production. She sang Amneris in <a href="Michigan%20Opera%20Theatre">Michigan Opera</a>'s production of "Aida", opposite her husband as Radames.
Nikolic' concert appearances have included a gala at La Scala and Rossini’s "<a href="Petite%20messe%20solennelle">Petite messe solennelle</a>" in Sardinia; she has performed in Mozart's "<a href="Requiem%20%28Mozart%29">Requiem</a>", Handel’s "<a href="Messiah%20%28Handel%29">Messiah</a>", and Verdi’s "<a href="Requiem%20%28Verdi%29">Missa da Requiem</a>" with <a href="Queensland%20Symphony%20Orchestra">The Queensland Orchestra</a> and the latter with the <a href="Adelaide%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Adelaide Symphony Orchestra</a>. She also appeared as soloist with the <a href="Auckland%20Philharmonia%20Orchestra">Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra</a>. In September 2008 she sang in Mendelssohn's oratorio "<a href="St.%20Paul%20%28oratorio%29">Paulus</a>". In May 2010 she gave a recital with her husband, the tenor Rosario La Spina and the pianist <a href="Tahu%20Matheson">Tahu Matheson</a>.
In November 2012 Nikolic and La Spina had a son.
Awards.
Nikolic has won awards at international competitions, including the <a href="Biserka%20Cveji%C4%87">Biserka Cvejić</a> Award as "most outstanding vocalist of the year 1998", the Nikola Cvejic Award as "most promising young singer" in the <a href="Petar%20Konjovi%C4%87">Petar Konjović</a> International Competition 1998. In 2001 she won first prize in the <a href="Ada%20Sari">Ada Sari</a> International Competition in <a href="Krak%C3%B3w">Kraków</a>.
